question.content: In ancient times, which river was also known as 'Pooni' in Tamil which is the fourth largest river flowing in the southeast direction through the states of Karnataka and Tamil Nadu?

solution.content: Kaveri River. It is a sacred river in southern India. It rises on Brahmagiri Hill of the Western Ghats in southwestern Karnataka state and drains into the Bay of Bengal through Pondicherry.

question.content: Which of the following rivers is also called Vyath?

solution.content: Jhelum River. Zanskar river, primarily known for its unique Chadar Trek or the Frozen River Trek, in Ladakh.

question.content: The Hundru Fall lies along the course of which of the following rivers?

solution.content: Subarnarekha. It is located in Ranchi District. Rajrappa waterfalls occur at the confluence of River Bhairavi and river Damodar.

question.content: Which of the following rivers flow through both the states, West Bengal and Sikkim?

solution.content: Teesta river originates in the Himalayas near Chunthang, Sikkim and flows to the south through West Bengal before entering Bangladesh.

question.content: The Hirakud Dam is built near the city of in Odisha.

solution.content: Sambalpur. Dam is a structure built across a stream or river to hold water back. Dams can be used to store water, control flooding, and generate electricity. Hirakud dam (Built on Mahanadi river) is the longest earthen dam in the world.

question.content: River Ken is one of the major rivers of the Bundelkhand region of central India and flows through two states, Madhya Pradesh and

solution.content: Uttar Pradesh. River Ken It is a tributary of the Yamuna. The important tributaries of Ken - Alona, Bearma, Sonar, Mirhasan, Shyamari, Banne, Kutri, Urmil, Kail and Chandrawal.

question.content: Which snow-fed river? of the following is a

solution.content: Yamuna. The Yamuna is the main and the longest right bank tributary of river Ganga. It is a snow-fed, braided river that rises from Yamunotri glacier near Bandarpoonch peak of the higher Himalaya.

question.content: Which of the following rivers form Kunchikal waterfall in Karnataka?

solution.content: Varahi. Kunchikal Falls is located in Nidagodu village near Masthikatte in Shimoga district of state Karnataka. It cascade down rocky boulders and the total height of fall is 455 meters.

question.content: The river Indus was called by the Iranians and the Greeks about 2500 years ago.

solution.content: Hindos. This word is derived from the Sanskrit word "Sindhu", which means "river".

question.content: Which of the following rivers flows into the Bay of Bengal?

solution.content: Mahanadi. The Mahanadi is one of the major east flowing peninsular rivers in India, originating in Dhamtari district of Chhattisgarh and draining into the Bay of Bengal.

question.content: About 50% of the Basin lies in Maharashtra.

solution.content: Godavari.

question.content: The groundwater stored between layers of hard rock below the water table is called:

solution.content: aquifer. Glaciers are formed when snow accumulates and compacts over time. Hot springs are formed when groundwater is heated by geothermal energy. Geysers are hot springs that periodically erupt, sending a column of hot water and steam into the air.

question.content: Which of the following is a tributary of Yamuna river?

solution.content: Chambal River. It forms part of the greater Gangetic drainage system. The Chambal and its tributaries drain the Malwa region of northwestern Madhya Pradesh, while its tributary, the Banas, rises in the Aravalli Range and drains southeastern Rajasthan.

question.content: On which of the following rivers is Pakistan constructing a dam named 'Diamer Basha' dam?

solution.content: Indus. It is located between Kohistan district in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Diamer district in Gilgit Baltistan, Pakistan administered Kashmir.

question.content: Which of the following waterfalls is in the state of Goa?

solution.content: Dudhsagar waterfall is a four-tiered waterfall located on the Mandovi River. Duduma Waterfall is situated on the border of Koraput (Odisha) and Visakhapatnam (Andhra Pradesh) districts of India. The Gokak Falls is a waterfall located on the Ghataprabha River in Belagavi district of Karnataka, India. The Shivasamudram Falls, located in the Chamarajanagar district and Mandya district of the state of Karnataka.

question.content: Which of the following is the largest west flowing river in Rajasthan?

solution.content: Luni. It originates in the Pushkar valley of the Aravalli Range, near Ajmer, passes through the southeastern portion of the Thar Desert, and ends in the marshy lands of Rann of Kutch in Gujarat.

question.content: The river Indus lies to the_ of the Great Indian Desert.

solution.content: West. The Thar Desert is bordered by the irrigated Indus River plain to the west, the Punjab Plain to the north and northeast, the Aravalli Range to the southeast, and the Rann of Kachchh to the south.

question.content: In which of the following states is the Bhambavli Vajrai Waterfall located?

solution.content: Maharashtra. The waterfall is situated in the district of Satara in western Maharashtra. Famous waterfalls in Maharashtra- Malshej Falls, Pandavkada waterfall, Randha Falls, Chinaman's Falls, Dhobi Waterfall, Sahastrakund waterfalls, Zenith Falls, Vihigaon Waterfall.

question.content: Which of the following states has the largest catchment area of Godavari Basin?

solution.content: Maharashtra. Banganga, Kadva, Shivana, Purna, Kadam, Pranahita, Indravati, Taliperu, Sabari, Nasardi, Pravara, Sindphana, Manjira, Manair, Kinnerasani are tributaries of Godavari river.

question.content: Which of the following river systems has Wardha river as one of its significant rivers?

solution.content: Godavari.

question.content: In which Indian state will you find the river Muhuri?

solution.content: Tripura. Muhuri is a transnational river between India and Bangladesh. Rising in Tripura, It flows into Bangladesh where it merges with the Feni near the latter's mouth to the Bay of Bengal.

question.content: In which Indian state is the 'Bhushi Lake' located?

solution.content: Maharashtra. Popular Lakes in Maharashtra - Upvan Lake, Vihar Lake, Powai Lake, Rankala Lake, Panshet Lake, Ganesh Lake, Venna Lake, Lonar Lake.

question.content: Which Indian state is the source of the rivers Brahmani, Kharkai and Subarnarekha?

solution.content: Jharkhand. Other rivers in Jharkhand Sone river, Barakar river, Damodar river, Ajay river, South Koel river, Shankh river, North Koel river.

question.content: Bhojtal, formerly known as Upper Lake, is situated in which of the following states?

solution.content: Madhya Pradesh. Famous Lakes: Madhya Pradesh The Lower Lake, Munj Sagar Lake, Yashwant Sagar; Uttar Pradesh - Keetham Lake; Odisha Ansupa Lake; Rajasthan Fateh Sagar Lake.

question.content: Which river marks the easternmost boundary of the Himalayas?

solution.content: Brahmaputra.

question.content: Gurdwara Patalpuri Sahib is located on the bank of river_

solution.content: Sutlej. Gurdwara Patalpuri Sahib located in Rupnagar district of Punjab. Guru Hargobind Ji in 1644 as well as Guru Har Rai Ji in 1661 were cremated here.

question.content: Which of the following is a tributary of the river Brahmaputra that flows through Bhutan?

solution.content: Wang Chhu River. Bhutan has four major rivers, named Drangme Chhu, Mo Chhu, Wang Chhu and Torsa Chhu. The Brahmaputra is one of the largest rivers of the Indian Subcontinent.

question.content: What is the name of the river formed by the confluence of Sankh River and South Koel River at Vedv yas in Odisha?

solution.content: Brahmani. It winds generally southeast past Bonaigarh and Talcher and then turns east to join northern branches of the Mahanadi River, which then empties into the Bay of Bengal at Palmyras Point.

question.content: In which of the following states is Anchar Lake located?

solution.content: Jammu and Kashmir. It is located near the Soura area in the city of Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir. The lake is connected with the famous Dal Lake.

question.content: Yerla, Warna and Dindi are tributaries of the _ river system.

solution.content: Krishna.

question.content: The river Ganga divides the state of Bihar into parts.

solution.content: 2. Parts of the state North Bihar and South Bihar. Ganga River enters Bihar through Bauxar district and exits from Bhagalpur district.

question.content: Where is the Jai Hind bridge located in India?

solution.content: Kolkata. Majerhat Bridge named "Jai Hind" to mark Subhas Chandra Bose's 125th birth anniversary.

question.content: A/an is a natural geo-hydrological unit of land, which collects water and drains it through a common point by a system of streams.

solution.content: Watershed. Types (In hectare): Macro watershed (> 50,000), Sub-watershed (10,000 to 50,000), Milli-watershed (1000 to 10000), Micro watershed (100 to 1000), Mini watershed (1-100).

question.content: Which of the following places is NOT located on the banks of river Ganga?

solution.content: Hazaribagh is a city and a municipal corporation in the Hazaribagh district in Jharkhand.

question.content: A channel of a canal where water flows under the influence of gravity is called

solution.content: flow channel. It is the flow of water induced by the effect of gravity. The surface of the flowing liquid is at atmospheric pressure and free to air. The example of open channel flow includes flow in canal, river, etc.

question.content: On which river is Peacock Island located?

solution.content: Brahmaputra. Peacock Island or Umananda Island is the smallest inhabited river island in the middle of river Brahmaputra, flowing through the city of Guwahati. Its name derives from Assamese Uma. It is also known as Bhasmachal.

question.content: Which of the following is Uttarakhand's first gravity dam?

solution.content: Song dam which is to be built on the foothills of Mussoorie on the Song river to meet the water shortage of the state during the summers.

question.content: Which one of the following is the longest river of Nepal?

solution.content: River Karnali also called Ghaghara is a perennial transboundary river originating on the Tibetan Plateau near Lake Manasarovar.

question.content: 'Ong' and 'Tel' are tributaries of the river_

solution.content: Mahanadi. Tributaries of Mahanadi - Seonath, Hideo, Jonk, Mand, Ib.

question.content: Which type of dam is a temporary dam constructed to exclude water the specific area?

solution.content: coffer. It is built to permit damming, diversion, or dewatering and construction of a permanent structure in a dry area. A detention dam is built to catch surface runoff and stream water flow to regulate the water flow in areas below the dam. Detention dams are commonly used to reduce the damage caused by flooding or to manage the flow rate through a channel.

question.content: Which of the following rivers rises in the west of Rohtang Pass in the Kullu hills of Himachal Pradesh and flows through the Chamba valley of the state?

solution.content: Ravi. It is the smallest river amongst the five rivers of Punjab. Punjab state is divided into Majha, Doaba and Malwa regions.

question.content: Suryadhar lake is located in which of the following states?

solution.content: Uttarakhand. Famous Lakes in Uttarakhand Auli Artificial Lake, Baraadsar Lake, Bedni Kund, Bhalu Dam, Bhimtal Lake, Bhulla Tal, Bisurital, Brahmatal Trek etc.

question.content: In which of the following states is the Sirki Waterfall located?

solution.content: Arunachal Pradesh. Other Waterfalls - The Nuranang Waterfall, the Bap Teng Kang Waterfall

question.content: Ujjain is on the banks of the river

solution.content: Kshipra (Tributary of the Chambal River). Ujjain was once the capital of the Avanti kingdom and is one of the 12 Jyotirlingas, or shrines of Shiva. The city is also home to the Mahakaleshwar Temple.

question.content: Which of the following is NOT one of the three parallel ranges of the Himalayas in its longitudinal extent?

solution.content: Himshikha. Shiwaliks (Lesser Himalayas): The outermost range, Himachal (Great Himalayas): Middle range, Himadri (Inner Himalayas): Inner range.

question.content: Which river has the tributaries by the name of Mayurakshi, Damodar, Kangsabati and Rupnarayan?

question.content: Which of the following crops can be grown during the Kharif season in India?

solution.content: Cotton. Kharif Crops : Sowing Season - Early May, with the onset of the first monsoon rains. Harvesting Months: Typically between October and November. Examples: Cotton, groundnut, maize, and rice. Rabi Crops: Sowing Season - Around mid-November, after the monsoon rains. Harvesting Months Generally between April and May. Examples - Barley, gram, peas, and wheat. Zaid Crops - Crops that are sown in March and harvested in June. Examples Muskmelon, Watermelon, Cucumber, Bitter gourd, Pumpkin etc.

question.content: Cultivating large farms with moderately low inputs of labour and capital is referred to as.

solution.content: Extensive cultivation The crop yield depends on the natural fertility of the soil, terrain, climate, availability of water. Example Grain Farming, shifting cultivation. Hybrid cultivation: It involves the use of hybrid seed varieties (created by crossbreeding two or more genetically distinct plants). Example Wheat Sonalika and Kalyan Sona, Rice Jaya and Ratna. Intensive cultivation - Large farms are being cultivated with high level use of capital and labor. Examples Greenhouse agriculture, Aquaculture. Capitalist cultivation - Farming activities are controlled and manipulated by individual entrepreneurs. Example Plantation farming.

question.content: Which of the following crops is classified as fine grain?

solution.content: Wheat. India produces a variety of cereals, which are classified as fine grains (Rice, Wheat) and Coarse grains - Jowar, Bajra, Maize, Ragi, etc. In West Bengal farmers grow three crops of rice called 'aus', 'aman' and 'boro'. But in the Himalayas and northwestern parts of the country, it is grown as a kharif crop during the southwest Monsoon season.

question.content: Match the columns. Names of Shifting Agriculture Related State I. Jhuming a) Madhya Pradesh II. Dahiya b) Andhra Pradesh III. Penda IV. Kumari c) North eastern region d) Western Ghats

solution.content: i-c, ii-a, iii-b, iv-d. Shifting cultivation (Slash and burn agriculture) - A plot of land is cleared by felling the trees and burning them. The ashes are then mixed with the soil and crops are grown. After the soil loses its fertility, the land is abandoned and the cultivator moves to a new plot. Known by different Names: Kaman, Vinga and Dhavi (Odisha), Batra (South-eastern Rajasthan), Podu (Andhra Pradesh), Milpa (Mexico), Roca (Brazil), Ladang (Malaysia).

question.content: Which of the following is the most suitable application of rainwater harvesting?

solution.content: Irrigation. question.content: What is meant by subsistence agriculture?

Agriculturists produce primarily for the market.

solution.content: Types of Subsistence Farming: primitive subsistence farming or shifting cultivation (oldest form of agriculture) It happens on a self-sufficient basis, and farmers raise food according to their family's needs. The trees are cut down and burnt and the cleared land is cultivated. Other names: Shifting cultivation or slash and burn cultivation. Intensive subsistence farming - The farmer cultivates a small plot of land using simple tools and more. More than one crop is cultivated during a year.

question.content: Which of these is NOT one of the negative effects of the green revolution?

question.content: The colour of the alluvial soils varies from_

solution.content: light grey to ash grey. Alluvial soils are formed by the deposition of sediments from rivers and streams. These sediments are typically composed of sand, silt, and clay, which are all light-coloured materials. The colour of the alluvial soils can also be affected by the presence of organic matter, which can give them a darker colour. Light orange to dark orange is the colour of laterite soils. Orange to red is the colour of red soils.

question.content: Which of the following is an example of micronutrient supplied by soil?

question.content: Which of the following pairs of 'soil - characteristics' is correct? I. Sandy - proportion of fine particles is relatively higher II. Clayey greater proportion of big particles

solution.content: Neither I nor II. Sandy Soil: Consists of small particles of weathered rock; One of the poorest types of soil for growing plants (very low nutrients and poor water holding capacity); Good for the drainage system; Usually formed by the breakdown or fragmentation of rocks like granite, limestone and quartz. Clay Soil: Smallest particles (tightly packed together with each other with very little or no airspace); Good water storage qualities; Very sticky to touch when wet but smooth when dried; Densest and heaviest type of soil which does not drain well or provide space for plant roots to flourish.

question.content: In which of the following soil conservation methods different crops are grown in alternate rows and are sown at different times to protect the soil from rain wash?

question.content: Identify the step that is NOT a part of decomposition.

question.content: What do you call the weight a soil can withstand before severe damage occurs to the structure of the soil?

solution.content: Bearing capacity is the capacity of soil to support the loads that are applied to the ground above. Field capacity is the amount of soil moisture or water content held in the soil after excess water has drained away and the rate of downward movement has decreased. Bulk density is defined as the mass of the many particles of the material divided by the total volume they occupy. Buffer capacity refers to the amount of acid or base a buffer can neutralise before the pH changes by a large amount.

C-horizon: This soil layer lies beneath the B horizon and consists essentially of the more or less weathered parent rock. The Himalayan ranges show change in vegetation from tropical to tundra. Since air is less dense at higher altitudes, its molecules are spread farther apart than they are at sea level. These molecules have fewer collisions, so they produce less heat. At the bottom of the mountain, the temperature is high year-round while it is much cooler at the top due to which it is covered with snow.

question.content: Under which strata do trees fall?

solution.content: Top vertical. Strata are layers of vegetation that are defined by the height of the plants. Second vertical - It contains the second-tallest plants in a forest ecosystem, such as shrubs and small trees. Bottom vertical - It contains the shortest plants in a forest ecosystem, such as mosses and ferns. Middle vertical - It contains the plants that are in between the top and bottom vertical strata, such as medium-sized shrubs and trees.

question.content: With reference to the major regions of the northern plains, Bhabar is:

options.text: the older alluvium along the river beds forming terraces higher than the floodplain
a narrow belt of about 8 to 16 km that runs in the west-east direction along the foot of the Himalayas from the river Indus to Teesta
composed of newer alluvium and forms flood plains along the river banks
a broad long zone of northern India and southern Nepal running parallel to the lower ranges of the Himalayas

answer: a narrow belt of about 8 to 16 km that runs in the west-east direction along the foot of the Himalayas from the river Indus to Teesta

solution.content: Bhabar is a narrow belt lying parallel to the slopes of the Shiwaliks in Uttarakhand. It is narrow in the east and wide in the western and northwestern hilly regions. It comprises gravel and un-assorted sediment deposits. Crop cultivation is not possible in this tract, only giant trees with deep roots grow.

question.content: The birth rate indicates the number of live births occurring during the year per 1000 population estimated at midyear.

solution.content: crude. Birth rate is the total number of live births in a particular area (an entire country, a state, a district or other territorial unit) during a specified period (usually a year) divided by the total population of that area in thousands. Death rate is expressed as the number of deaths in a given area during a given time per 1000 population. Rate of natural increase refers to the difference between the birth rate and the death rate.

solution.content: Stratosphere- Its height of the bottom varies with latitude and with the seasons. Aviation & Jet Streams fly in the Stratosphere.

question.content: In which layer of atmosphere does the meteorites burn up on entering from space?

solution.content: Mesosphere. Meteorites are space rocks that fall to Earth's surface. Meteorites are the last stage in the existence of these types of space rocks.

question.content: How much percentage of oxygen is present in the atmosphere?

solution.content: 21%. Percentage of Gases by Volume in Atmosphere: Nitrogen (78.08%), Oxygen (20.95%), Argon (0.93%), Carbon dioxide (0.036%), Neon (0.002%), Helium (0.0005%), Hydrogen (0.00005%), etc. The atmosphere contains a mixture of gases and huge numbers of Aerosols (solid and liquid particles).

question.content: Which layer of atmosphere helps in radio transmission?

solution.content: Thermosphere. The temperature starts increasing again with increasing height in this layer. Aurora and satellites occur in this layer.

question.content: What is the average temperature of Chennai in the cold season?

solution.content: 24° - 25° Celsius. Chennai has warm temperatures year round ranging between 29°C (84°F) and 37°C (98°F). {Coldest month (January 29°C (84°F)). Chennai features a tropical wet and dry climate. Chennai lies on the thermal equator and is also coastal, which prevents extreme variation in seasonal temperature.

question.content: People of have hardly any idea of extremes of temperature and the seasons rhythm of weather.

solution.content: Mumbai has moderate climate as it is along the shoreline of Arabian Sea.

question.content: In India, from June to September which type of weather prevails?

solution.content: Monsoon / Rainy season. Major seasons in India: Rainy {(Southwest Monsoon Season) June to September), Autumn {(Season of Retreating Monsoon) October and November), Winter {(Cold Weather Season) December to February}, and Summer {(Hot Weather Season) March to May}.

question.content: At what height do the Jet Streams blow in India during winter months?

solution.content: 9-13 km. Jet Streams (geostrophic wind) are relatively narrow bands of strong wind. Types: Polar-Night Jet Stream, SubTropical Jet Streams (westerlies), Tropical Easterly Jet Stream.

question.content: Which cycle shows the movement of water?

solution.content: Hydrological cycle. Carbon cycle shows the movement of carbon in elemental and combined states on earth. The nitrogen cycle is a series of processes that convert nitrogen gas to organic substances and back to nitrogen in nature. The Geological cycle refers to a series of intertwined processes that are important for the formation and break down of physical Earth features.

question.content: The climate of Assam can be described as:

solution.content: Tropical Monsoon Rainforest Climate. Tropical monsoon climates have monthly mean temperatures above 18 °C (64 °F) in every month of the year and a dry season. Tropical monsoon climate is the intermediate climate between the wet Af (or tropical wet climate) and the drier Aw (or tropical savanna climate).

question.content: _is a naturally occurring phenomenon that is responsible for the heating of the Earth's surface and atmosphere.

solution.content: Greenhouse Effect. When the Sun's energy reaches the Earth's atmosphere, some of it is reflected back to space and the rest is absorbed and re-radiated by greenhouse gases. The absorbed energy warms the atmosphere and the surface of the Earth.

question.content: Which statement best explains why Shillong gets around 200 cm rainfall annually; whereas Cherrapunji, which is around 30 km away (as the crow flies), gets over 1250 cm of rainfall annually?

options.text: Cherrapunji gets rainfall from rain-laden clouds coming from the Himalayas, whereas Shillong gets rainfall from the Malabar branch of monsoon.
Cherrapunji lies on the leeward side of the Khasi hills and Shillong lies on the windward side of the Khasi hills, and thus, gets only wind and no rain.
The average temperature of Shillong has gone up due to excessive deforestation and pollution.

Cherrapunji lies on the windward side of the Khasi hills and receives rainfall from the Bay of Bengal branch of monsoon, while Shillong lies on the leeward side of the Khasi hills, which forms the rain shadow area.

answer: Cherrapunji lies on the windward side of the Khasi hills and receives rainfall from the Bay of Bengal branch of monsoon, while Shillong lies on the leeward side of the Khasi hills, which forms the rain shadow area.

solution.content: Cherrapunji, also known as Sohra, is a high-altitude town in the northeast Indian state of Meghalaya, is renowned for its unique living root bridges.

question.content: Cirrus and cumulus are types of

solution.content: Clouds. Cirrus clouds are wispy, veil-like clouds that form in the upper troposphere while cumulus clouds are stacked, dense and fluffy and they form much closer to the ground.

question.content: phenomenon synthetic Which has been environmental chemicals chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs)? linked

solution.content: Ozone depletion. Ozone depletion can cause increased amounts of UV radiation to reach the Earth which can lead to more cases of skin cancer, cataracts, and impaired immune systems.

question.content: Above which layer of atmosphere does the Exosphere lie?

solution.content: Thermosphere. The exosphere is the very edge of our atmosphere. This layer separates the rest of the atmosphere from outer space.

question.content: The term 'monsoon' is derived from a/an:

solution.content: Arabic word 'mausim', which means weather. The term was reportedly first used in English in British India and refers to the seasonal change in the direction of the prevailing winds of a region. Rocks

question.content: Which of the following is the correct match between column-A and column-В? Column-A (Type of rock) i. Sedimentary Rock ii. Metamorphic Rock iii. Igneous Rock Column-В (Method of formation) a. Transformed its chemical qualities from other type of rocks b. Derived from magma that was poured out or ejected at the Earth's Surface c. Formed from fragments of other rocks or the remains of plants or animals

solution.content: i-c, ii-a, iii-b. The rock cycle is a web of processes that outlines how each of the three major rock types igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary - form and break down based on the different applications of heat and pressure over time. Igneous rocks (Granite, gabbro, pegmatite, basalt). Sedimentary Rocks (Sandstone, limestone, shale, chalk). Metamorphic Rocks (Gneissoid, Syenite, Slate, Schist, Marble, quartzite).

question.content: Structural geology deals with:

options.text: the components and chemical nature of soil
the form, classification, mechanism, and causes of rock structures' evolution

answer: the form, classification, mechanism, and causes of rock structures' evolution

solution.content: Petrology is the science of rocks. Rock: Any natural mass of mineral matter that makes up the Earth's crust. On the basis of their mode of formation rocks are classified in 3 types (i) Igneous Rocks solidified from magma and lava; (ii) Sedimentary Rocks The result of deposition of fragments of rocks by exogenous processes; (iii) Metamorphic Rocks Formed out of existing rocks undergoing recrystallisation.

question.content: Which of the following is a yellowish green to green coloured gemstone often found in mafic and ultramafic igneous rocks such as basalt, gabbro, dunite, diabase and peridotite?

solution.content: Olivine. The mineral olivine is a magnesium iron silicate with the chemical formula (Mg,Fe)2SiO4. It is a type of nesosilicate or orthosilicate. Bornite, also known as peacock ore, is a sulfide mineral with a chemical composition of CuFeS4. Tremolite is a member of the amphibole group of silicate minerals with composition of Ca2MgsSigO22(OH)2. Garnets are a group of silicate minerals All species of garnets possess similar physical properties and crystal forms, but differ in chemical composition.

question.content: The breaking up of the rocks on the earth's surface is called as

solution.content: Weathering - The process of wearing, breaking up, and fragmentation of the rock that creates the surface of the ground and that remains exposed to the weather.

question.content: Which type of rock can be considered as a biological sedimentary rock?

solution.content: Limestone. Depending upon the mode of formation, sedimentary rocks are categorized into three groups Mechanically formed (Eg: Sandstone, conglomerate, limestone, shale, loess, etc.), Chemically formed (Eg: Chert, limestone, halite, potash, etc.), Organically formed or Biologic sedimentary rocks formed when living organisms die, pile up, and are then compressed and cemented together. Example - coal (from plants), limestone and coquina (from marine organisms), Geyserite, chalk, etc.

question.content: Which of the following is a characteristic of sedimentary rocks?

solution.content: Lithification includes all the processes which convert unconsolidated sediments into sedimentary rocks. Foliation in geology refers to repetitive layering in metamorphic rocks. Banding means that the rock consists of alternating, thin layers of two different mineral compositions.

question.content: The steep rocky coast rising almost vertically above sea water is called

solution.content: Sea cliffs are steep faces of rock and soil that are formed by destructive waves. A Sea cave is a cave formed on a cliff by the wave action of an ocean or lake. A sea arch is a natural arch or bridge made of stone that has been created when water wears away the underside of a rock, leaving just the top behind.

question.content: The core of the Great Himalayas is composed of

solution.content: Granite rock (Igneous rock). Lesser Himalaya consists of metamorphosed sedimentary rocks (quartzite, marble, slate, phyllite, schist and gneiss). Q.781 Which of the following determines the colour, texture,chemical properties, mineral, content and permeability of the soil? SSC MTS 22/07/2022 (Morning) (a) Parent rock (c) Relief (b) Time (d) Climate Sol.781.(a) Parent rock. The color in the soil is mainly due to two factors organic content and the chemical nature of iron compounds found in the soil.

question.content: How many types of igneous rocks are there?

solution.content: Two. Based on the texture of rocks, igneous rocks are classified into Intrusive igneous rocks (Plutonic rocks) and Extrusive igneous rocks (Lava or Volcanic rocks).

question.content: Mushroom rocks are formed due to _

solution.content: Wind erosion. A mushroom rock (perched rock) is a typical mushroom-shaped landform that is formed by the action of wind erosion. These rocks are mostly found in arid regions. Such rocks are found in the Thar Desert of India.

question.content: What type of rocks were once igneous or sedimentary, but have metamorphosed as a result of intense heat and/or pressure within the Earth's crust?

solution.content: Quartzite. Granite is a coarse-grained (phaneritic) intrusive igneous rock composed mostly of quartz, alkali feldspar, and plagioclase. Sandstone is a clastic sedimentary rock composed mainly of sand-sized silicate grains. Basalt is a mafic extrusive rock, is the most widespread of all igneous rocks, and comprises more than 90% of all volcanic rocks.

question.content: Which of the following rocks floats in water?

solution.content: Pumice is a light-colored, extremely porous igneous rock that forms during explosive volcanic eruptions. Obsidian has been used across history to make weapons, implements, tools, ornaments, and mirrors. Granites are a type of hard and compact igneous rock formed by quartz, feldspar, as well as mica. Slate is a type of metamorphic rock.

question.content: plains are formed due to the weathering of soluble rocks such as limestone and dolomite.

solution.content: Karst regions contain aquifers that are capable of providing large supplies of water. Typical karst forms include sinkholes, caves, natural bridges and sinking streams. Mountain

question.content: The Garo, Khasi and Jaintia hills are a subdivision of:

solution.content: Meghalaya Plateau. The plateau is separated from the main block of the peninsular plateau by a gap called the Garo-RajMahal gap. It is located on the northeastern flank of Peninsular India. It is one of the rainiest, most tectonically active areas in the world. Hills in North East India - Lushai Hills or Mizo Hills (Mizoram and Tripura), Chin Hills (Manipur to Chin State of Myanmar), Barail Range (Assam), Dafla Hills and Abor Hills (Arunachal Pradesh).

question.content: The Karewa formations are found in the

solution.content: Kashmir Himalayas. The Karewa term means "elevated table land". Firstly, this term was used by Godwin Austin in 1859. "Vudr" is the local name for it in Kashmiri language. Karewa formations are useful for the cultivation of Zafran (Saffron), almond, walnut, apple, and orchards in Kashmir valley.

question.content: Siachen in Himalayas is:

solution.content: A glacier. The Siachen Glacier is located in the Eastern Karakoram range in the Himalayas. It is the world's highest battlefield. Nubra river originates from Siachen Glacier. It is situated to the North of Nubra Valley.

question.content: The holy mountain 'Kailash' is located in which neighbouring country of India?

solution.content: China. Mount Kailash - Located near Lake Mansarovar and Lake Rakshastal. The Indus River originates from Mansarovar lake (Tibet). Some highest mountain peaks: India Kanchenjunga (8598m), Nanda Devi (7817m). Nepal - Mount Everest (8848.86 m), Dhaulagiri (8172m). Hindu temple outside India: Nepal Pashupatinath Temple, Indonesia Prambanan Temple, Bangladesh Dhakeshwari temple, Cambodia - Angkor Wat.

question.content: Which of the following hills are located in Purvachal?

solution.content: Mizo hills and Naga hills. The Patkai Bum, Mizo Hills or Lushai Hills and Naga Hills are mountain ranges in Northeastern India. Shevaroy hills (Tamil Nadu) and Javadi hills (Tamil Nadu). Khasi and Jaintia hills (Meghalaya). Anamudi (Kerala) and Doda Betta (Tamil Nadu).

question.content: Which mountain range from the following is associated with Rajasthan state?

solution.content: Aravali Range. It lies on the western and northwestern margins of the Peninsular Plateau. They extend from Gujarat to Delhi in a southwest-northeast direction. The Guru Shikhar (1722m) is the highest peak of the Aravalli range. Important passes (Rajasthan): Goran Ghat, Haldighati Pass. River Sabarmati originates from the Aravali ranges.

question.content: Identify the southernmost range of the Himalaya from the following.

solution.content: Siwaliks Range. Himalayan Ranges: Himadri (Greater Himalayas or Inner Himalayas), Himachal (Lesser Himalayas), Shiwaliks (Outer Himalayas). Divisions (West to east) : Punjab Himalayas (between rivers Indus and Sutlej), Kumaon Himalayas (Between Sutlej and Kali rivers), Nepal Himalayas (between rivers Kali and Teesta), Assam Himalayas (between rivers Tista and Dihang), Purvanchal (beyond the Dihang river).

question.content: The western Ghats and the Eastern Ghats meet at which of the following places in southern India?

solution.content: Nilgiri Hills: Highest Peak Doda Betta. Located at the tri-junction of the states of Karnataka, Kerala and Tamil Nadu. Named after the Neelakurinji flowers (purplish-blue flowers) found in Shola forests. Satpura Hills - The range begins in eastern Gujarat and runs east through Maharashtra and Madhya Pradesh before ending in Chhattisgarh. Nallamala Hills Andhra Pradesh, eastern ghats. Mahendragiri Hills is located in the district of Gajapati, Odisha (eastern ghats).

question.content: Name an oval-shaped range of hills sculpted by glacial flow.

solution.content: Drumlins - It is formed by the filling of heavy rocky debris in the glacial crevices and its stay under the ice. One end of the drumlins facing the glacier called the stoss end and the other end called tail. Eskers: When glaciers melt in summer, the water flows on the surface of the ice. These waters accumulate beneath the glacier and flow like streams in a channel beneath the ice. Moraine: Materials (Soil and Rock) left behind by a moving glacier.

question.content: The Japfu range, which is 3,014 meters high, is located in which state?

solution.content: Nagaland. Mt. Japfu is called the Switzerland of the East. Other peaks: Nagaland Kapu, Zanubou, Glory Peak, Zephu. Meghalaya Garo (Nokrek is the highest point), Khasi, and Jaintia hills. Assam - Barail is the highest hill range. Arunachal Pradesh - Mishmi, Dafla range, Namcha Barwa.

question.content: In which part of the Indian Himalayas does its highest mountain peak, Kanchenjunga, lie?

solution.content: The Darjeeling and Sikkim Himalayas. Kanchenjunga is the world's third-highest mountain, with an elevation of (8,598 meters). The mountain is part of the Greater Himalayas or Himadri Range. It is delimited in the west by the Tamur River, in the north by Lhonak Chu and Jongsang La, and in the east by the Teesta River. Other Mountains and their states Nanda Devi (Uttarakhand), Anamudi (Kerala), Doddabetta (Tamil Nadu), Guru shikhar (Rajasthan).

question.content: The Shevaroy Hills are located in which state of India?

solution.content: Tamil Nadu (Aanna Malai, Doddabetta, Nilgiri). Famous hills:- Chhattisgarh Tulasi Dongar, Bailadila, Balaraja Gutta. Odisha Devmali, Turia Konda, Mahendragiri, Devagiri. Rajasthan Guru Shikhar, Mt. Abu, Sunda. Kangchenjunga (Sikkim)- Highest mountain peak in India. Jindhagada Peak (Andhra pradesh) Highest peak of Eastern Ghats. Anamudi (Kerala) Highest peak of Western Ghats.

question.content: Which among the following is the highest peak of West Bengal?

solution.content: Sandakphu (3636 m). It is located on the border between India and Nepal, belongs to the Singalia Mountain ranges. It is a part of the Purvanchal range. Doddabetta (2637 m) - It is the highest peak of Tamil Nadu and a part of Nilgiri Mountain Range.

question.content: The Himalayan Mountain range was formed by the collision of

solution.content: Indian Plate and Eurasian Plate. Plates They are large, rigid pieces of the Earth's lithosphere that fit together like a jigsaw puzzle, and their movements are responsible for shaping the Earth's surface through processes such as earthquakes and the formation of mountains. Major plates (7) - African Plate, Antarctic Plate, Eurasian Plate, North American Plate, South American Plate, Pacific Plate and Indo-Australian Plate.

question.content: The rock shelters of Bhimbetka are in the foothills of which mountains?

solution.content: Vindhyan (Raisen district, Madhya Pradesh). Bhimbetka In 1957, V. S. Wakankar discovered this site. It is inside the Ratapani Wildlife Sanctuary and declared as a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 2003. Other caves in Vindhya Range: Pandav Caves, Udayagiri Caves, Adamgarh Caves, Chota Mahadev Cave etc.

question.content: Dhinodhar Hills is located in which Indian state/Union Territory?

solution.content: Gujarat. Dhinodhar Hill is a tourist and pilgrimage spot. Other hills in Gujarat- Chotila, Pavagadh, Palitana, Saputara, Girnar, Bardo, Gabbar. Hills Maharashtra Mahabaleshwar, Panchgani, Matheran, Lonavala, Amboli etc. West Bengal- Gorgaburu Hill, Ajodhya Hills, Susunia Hill etc. Andaman and Nicobar Islands - Ross Island, Barren Island, Saddle Peak, Katchal, Narcondam Island etc.

question.content: Which among the following peaks is the highest peak of Jharkhand?

solution.content: Parasnath. It is named after Lord Parshvanath (23rd Jain Tirthankara). Anamudi peak (Kerala) and Kangto peak (Arunachal Pradesh). State and Highest Peak - Gujarat (Girnar Peak), Rajasthan (Guru Shikhar), Andhra Pradesh (Arma Konda), Haryana (Karah Peak), Karnataka (Mullayanagiri Peak).

question.content: Which of the following statements is NOT correct?

options.text: Mahendragiri is the highest peak in the Eastern Ghats.
The height of the Western Ghats progressively decreases from north to south.
The Western Ghats cause orographic rain.
The Eastern Ghats stretch from the Mahanadi Valley to the Nilgiris in the south.

answer: The height of the Western Ghats progressively decreases from north to south.

solution.content: The height of the Western Ghats progressively increases from north to south. The highest peaks of Western Ghats include the Anai Mudi (2,695 metres) and the Doda Betta (2,637 meters).The Western Ghats, also known as the Sahyadri Hills, Mainly traverse the States of Kerala, Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Goa, Maharashtra and Gujarat.

question.content: Which among the following glaciers is not located in Jammu & Kashmir?

solution.content: Milam (Uttarakhand). Glaciers of Himachal Pradesh: Bara Shigri, Chota Shigri, Gefang Glacier, Chandra glacier, Milang glacier, Bhaga glacier, Malana Glacier.

question.content: Which of the following hills are NOT part of the Purvanchal hills?

solution.content: Patli hills (Himachal). The Purvanchal Hills are a range of hills in northeastern India, located in Assam, Arunachal Pradesh, and Nagaland. Its major ranges - The Dafla Hills, Patkai Hills, Khasi Hills, Jaintia Hills and Mishmi Hills.

question.content: Which among the following is the largest of all the duns of the Shiwaliks mountain range in India?

solution.content: Dehradun (Length 35-45 km, Width - 22-25 km). Dun- Valleys that lie between the Shivalik and Lesser himalaya. Other duns of Uttarakhand Kota dun, Patli dun, Har ki dun. Kotli dun - Himachal Pradesh. Kashmir Himalayas Jammu dun and Pathankot dun.

question.content: Kalsubai peak is located in which of the following Indian states?

solution.content: Maharashtra. Kalsubai (Everest of Maharashtra) is the highest peak of Maharashtra's Ahmednagar district in Akola taluka. Other Highest Peaks and related states: Mount Dhupgarh or Dhupgarh Mahadeo Hills (Satpura Range), Madhya Pradesh; Arma Konda (Sitamma Konda) Andhra Pradesh; Guru Shikhar - Aravalli Range in Rajasthan.

question.content: Which of the following is NOT a type of a fold mountain?

solution.content: Rhine Valley. Fold mountains are the most common type of mountain in the world. The rugged, soaring heights of the Himalayas, Andes, Alps and Aravalli Range (oldest range) are all active fold mountains. Rhine Valley (Germany) is the valley of the river Rhine in Europe. It is also known as Alpine Rhine. The Appalachian Mountains are found in North America.

question.content: The approximate length of the Great Himalayan range, also known as the central axial range, is _ km from east to west.

solution.content: 2500. The great Himalayan range width varies between 160-400 km from north to south. Famous peaks of Himalayas: Mount Everest (8848 m), Mt. Kanchenjunga (8598 m), Mt. Makalu (8481 m), Mt. Dhaulagiri (8172 m). The Himalayas consist of three parallel ranges - Himadri (Great Himalayas or the Higher Himalayas), Himachal (Lesser Himalayas or the Lower Himalayas) and Shiwaliks (Outer Himalayas).

question.content: What is the average height of inner Himalayas?

solution.content: 6000 metres. The Himalayas consist of three parallel ranges, the Greater Himalayas or the Inner Himalayas or the Himadri, the Lesser Himalayas called the Himachal (with an average height of 3,700 to 4500 meters), and the Shivalik hills (with an average height of 900 to 1100 meters), which comprise the foothills.

question.content: Asia is separated from Europe by _ mountains.

solution.content: Ural. Alps mountain (natural boundary between France and Italy), Andes Mountains range (South American countries of Chile and Argentina), Himalaya (plains of the Indian subcontinent from the Tibetan Plateau). Caucasus mountains (Asia and Europe). have

question.content: Which of the following mountain range young fold mountains?

solution.content: Alps mountain range. Fold mountains form when two or more of the Earth's tectonic plates collide. Types Anticline, Syncline, Monocline, Isocline. Features - rugged relief, imposing height (lofty), high conical peaks. Examples are the Rockies, the Andes, the Alps, the Himalayas, etc. Old fold Mountain - An Appalachian mountain range, Aravali mountain range, and Ural mountain range.

question.content: The uplifted blocks of block mountains are called_

solution.content: Horsts. Block mountains are formed due to the upward movement of the middle block between two normal faults. The up-thrown block is also called a horst. Graben is bounded by normal faults dipping toward each other. These mountains include the Great African Rift Valley, the Rhine Valley (graben) in Germany, etc.

question.content: Which of the following mountains is formed as a result of the compression of tectonic plates, leading to the formation of large fold-like structures on the Earth's crust?

solution.content: Ural mountain in Russia. Fold Mountains - Himalayan Mountains in Asia, the Alps in Europe, the Andes in South America, the Rockies in North America.

question.content: Which of the following mountains were formed when molten rock from the depths of the earth rose from the crust and piled up on its own?

solution.content: Mount Kilimanjaro in Africa (Tanzania). Top mountains in Africa:- Mount Kenya, Mount Stanley, Mount Speke, Mount Baker, Mount Emin.

question.content: Correctly match the following peaks of the Himalayas to their heights.

question.content: Which of the following is also known as the 'White Mountain'?

solution.content: Dhaulagiri mountain massif of the Himalayas in west-central Nepal. Cho Oyu, mountain, in the Himalayas on the Nepalese-Tibetan (Chinese) border. Makalu Mountain is located in the Mahalangur Himalayas 19 km southeast of Mount Everest, on the border between Nepal and Tibet. Lhotse Mountain - The main summit is on the border between Tibet and the Khumbu region of Nepal.

question.content: Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct regarding mountains? I - Mountains may be arranged in a line known as range. question.content: In which Indian state willyou find Mount Tiyi?

question.content: In which of the following Indian states will you find the Netarhat Mountains, also called 'Queen of Chotanagpur'?

question.content: In which of the following Indian states is the Gorichen peak located?

question.content: Mountaineers refer to altitudes above about_meters as the 'death zone'.

question.content: In which of the following states is Vindhya Range NOT located?

question.content: Which of the following is a mountain peak that rises above the surrounding peaks at the mountainous border of the Indian state of Nagaland and the Sagaing region of Myanmar?

question.content: Which Indian city has the Nilachal Hills?

question.content: Generally, a steep hill with an elevation of more than_ meters is classified as a mountain.

solution.content: 600. Within the earth, a continuous movement is taking place. The internal process leads to the upliftment and sinking of the earth's surface at several places. The external process is the continuous wearing down and rebuilding of the land surface. Eg: Erosion and Deposition.

question.content: Which of the following mountain ranges is home to the second highest peak of the world, K2?

solution.content: Karakoram Ranges is known as the 'backbone of high Asia'. It is also known as Krishnagiri which is situated in the northernmost range of the Trans-Himalayan ranges.

question.content: is created by the collision of convergent plate boundaries.

solution.content: Mountain building. A convergent boundary is an area on earth where two or more lithospheric plates converge or collide and one plate eventually slides beneath the other.

question.content: Which of the following Himalayan peaks is NOT located in Nepal?

solution.content: Kamet is the second highest mountain in the Garhwal region of Uttarakhand.

question.content: 'Pidurutalagala' is the highest mountain peak in

solution.content: Sri Lanka. Pidurutalagala or Mount Pedro in English, is an ultra prominent peak and the tallest mountain in Sri Lanka, at 2,524 m situated in the town of Nuwara Eliya.

question.content: Which of the following hills is situated in Assam?

question.content: Which ecological law states that body form or shape is linear in warm climates and more rounded and compact in cold climates ?

Gloger's rule states that endothermic animals of more humid climates tend to be more darkly pigmented than those of drier climates.

question.content: Which of the following pairs of "term - definition" is correct? 1. Strait a narrow strip of land joining two landmasses II. Isthmus - a narrow passage of water connecting two large water bodies

solution.content: Neither I nor II. Strait Narrow body of water that connects two larger bodies of water, Examples Cook strait (New Zealand), Malacca strait (Indonesia-Malaysia), Mesina strait (Italy-Sicily), Bering strait (Alaska -Russia), Hormuz strait (Gulf of persia-Gulf of Oman), etc. Isthmus narrow strip of land that connects two larger landmasses and separates two bodies of water, Examples - Isthmus of Panama, Isthmus of suez.

question.content: In 1962, who published 'The History of Ocean Basins', which outlined the theory of how tectonic plates could move, later called 'sea floor spreading'? SSC CGL Tier II 03/03/2023

solution.content: Harry Hammond Hess. According to the theory of plate tectonics, the earth's lithosphere is broken into distinct plates which are floating on a ductile layer called asthenosphere.

question.content: Below are a few statements given about afforestation. A. Afforestation could prevent flooding. B. Afforestation can balance our ecosystem. Which of the above statements is/are correct? SSC CGL Tier II 03/03/2023

solution.content: Both A and B. Afforestation: process of planting trees and establishing forests in areas where they did not previously exist.

question.content: The national census does NOT recognise groups within India. SSC CGL Tier II 06/03/2023

solution.content: Ethnic. Census - Process of collecting, compiling, analyzing and disseminating demographic, economic and social data pertaining, at a specific time, of all persons in a country or a well-defined part of a country.

question.content: 'Anaconda, one of the world's largest snakes, is found in

solution.content: Tropical Evergreen Forests (Amazon forest). They are categorized under the genus Eunectes (great swimmers) and family (Boidae). They thrive very well in hot, humid places with dense foliage. Tropical rainforests are found in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia around the equator.

question.content: Wearing away of landscape by different agents like water, wind and ice is called

solution.content: Erosion. Metamorphism is the transformation of existing rock to rock with a different mineral composition or texture. Sedimentation refers to the process of particles settling out from the suspension of water because of the effect of gravity.

question.content: According to the field guide 'Birds of India' authored by the Zoological Survey of India, how many bird species are there in India?

solution.content: 1,331. ZSI: Founded (1 July 1916), Headquarters (Kolkata), Director (Dr Kailash Chandra, Dec.2022), Parent Organization (Ministry of Environment, forest, and Climate Change).

question.content: The study of the structure, evolution and dynamics of Earth and its natural mineral and energy resources is called:

solution.content: Geology. James Hutton is known as the father of geology. Eratosthenes is called the father of geography. The study of mountains is called Orology. The study of Rocks is called Petrology.

question.content: Which floating fern damages aquatic ecosystems by outgrowing and replacing native plants that provide food and habitat for native animals and waterflow?

solution.content: Giant salvinia (aquatic fern, native to south-eastern Brazil, Scientific name- Salvinia molesta). Salvinia minima (common salvinia or water spangles), Osmunda regalis (Royal fern), Azolla pinnata (mosquito fern, feathered mosquito fern and water velvet).

question.content: The process of wastewater treatment is commonly called _ treatment.

solution.content: Sewage. The 4 steps of sewage treatment are Sludge Thickening,Sludge Digestion, Dewatering, Disposal.

question.content: _ refers to a sanitation system in which toilets collect human excreta in sealable, removable cartridges that are transported to treatment facilities.

solution.content: Container Based Sanitation. Ecological sanitation is that protects human and ecosystem health while preventing water pollution, conserving energy, and capturing nutrients.

question.content: The greater one-horned rhino is listed under the Schedule of the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972

solution.content: I. Wildlife Protection Act, 1972 - Provides for the protection of wild animals, birds and plants.

question.content: In which of the following towns will you find the 'Kachari Ruins'?

solution.content: Dimapur (Nagaland). The Kachari Rajbari Ruins are a series of mushroom domed pillars.

question.content: _ is an environmental policy under which producers are given a significant responsibility- financial and/or physical - for the treatment or disposal of products that are no longer useful to the consumer

solution.content: Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR). The concept was first formally introduced in Sweden by Thomas Lindhqvist in 1990.

question.content: Which of the following is NOT a broad mitigation technique of landslide?

options.text: Construction of retention wall to stop land from slipping
The surface drainage control works to control the movement of landslide along with rain water and spring flows
Hazard mapping to locate areas prone to landslides
Reduction in the vegetation cover to arrest landslide

answer: Reduction in the vegetation cover to arrest landslide

solution.content: Landslide is the movement of a mass of rock, debris or earth down a slope. 4 types of landslides: fall and toppling, slides (rotational and translational), flows and creep.

question.content: Famines caused by rat infestation during the flowering of Melocanna baccifera bamboo in parts of North-East India is known as the''famines.

solution.content: Mautam. The Chalisa famine of 1783-1784 in the Indian subcontinent followed unusual El Niño events that began in 1780 and caused droughts throughout the region. The Doab famine of 1860-1861 was a famine in India that affected the Ganga-Yamuna Doab in the North-Western Provinces. The Doji bara famine (also Skull famine) of 1791-1792 in the Indian subcontinent was brought on by a major El Niño event lasting from 1789-1795 and producing prolonged droughts. 78/78
